title: Rotational Kinetic Energy Density and an Effective Mass Relation in Incompressible Fluids
description: This article derives a simple, fully classical benchmark for how rotational motion contributes to effective mass density in an incompressible, inviscid fluid. We consider a Newtonian fluid undergoing rigid-body rotation in a finite cylinder and compute the exact volume-averaged kinetic energy density from the velocity field \( {v}(r) = \Omega r\,\hat{{\theta}} \). Using the relativistic relation \( E = mc^2 \) in the low-velocity limit, we define an effective mass density \( \Delta \rho_{{eff}} = \langle e_{\mathrm{kin}} \rangle / c^2 \) and obtain the closed-form result \( \Delta \rho_{\mathrm{eff}} / \rho = \tfrac{1}{4} (v_{\mathrm{edge}}/c)^2 \), where \( v_{\mathrm{edge}} = \Omega R \) is the tangential speed at the cylinder boundary. The paper provides dimensional checks and numerical estimates for laboratory and astrophysical parameters, and situates the result within the standard framework of relativistic continuum mechanics and the stress–energy tensor. All calculations use only incompressible Euler flow and special relativity, offering a transparent reference case for the contribution of rotational kinetic energy to mass density without invoking any nonstandard physics.
